name: Emily
comment info:
According to the graphs, people make friends in high school and at work the least, with their rates being similar and more evenly spread through incomes than the “in college” and “in the neighborhood graphs.” The “in the neighborhood” graph has much higher rates of friendship than the “in high school” and “at work” graphs, is skewed right, and is clustered on the low-income side. The “in college” graph shows the highest rates of friendship, is skewed left, and is clustered on the high-income side. Low-income people were most likely to make friends in their neighborhood and high-income people were most likely to make friends in college. 
2: Does the question ask where the person had made the most friends in their life or where the person made lasting friends? 
3: As a low-income person, the graphs suggest that I would be most likely to make friends in my neighborhood. Even though I live in a neighborhood with a lot of people close together, I have never made friends in my neighborhood or any neighborhood I have lived in. It was surprising to me that the friendship rates in neighborhoods were so high in the graphs.
What’s going on in the graph? 
The graph shows where the friendship rates in common places in a person’s life were high and low and if there was a correlation between friendship rates in a location and income level.

What do you notice? If your notice makes a claim, where in the graph is the evidence to support it?

I notice that people in higher income tiers make more friends in college than people in lower income tiers do. The very high positive correlation in the graph between income level and number of friends from college supports my claim.


What do you wonder? 

I wonder about the causal relationship between income and college friendships. There is a positive correlation between income and education level. Those who attend college tend to earn higher incomes, so as the income level increases, the percentage of individuals who have attended college increases. This logically should result in a higher number of friendships made in college. Also, it is possible that those who are more effective at networking in college are also more likely to utilize those networks to earn more income in their careers. Lastly, those who are born to parents who are college educated are more likely to attend college (often as legacies) and have a head start in both college networking and gaining access to higher income careers.

I noticed the “In high school” and “At work” income levels followed the same pattern with a roughly normal, symmetrical shape. The “In college” and “In the neighborhood” were skewed left and right respectively.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s graph shows the results of a large sample of Americans, all Facebook users.  It displays the proportion of friends met by setting. The sample is subdivided into income percentiles so a comparison can be made between where higher and lower income groups for this setting meet their friends.  

Note:  These graphs show proportions and not numbers.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online for the four questions.  We have added a suggestion to the “What do you notice?” question.  If your notice includes a claim, please back it up with evidence that supports your claim.  

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the free link to the online article that included these graphs.  

You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Feb. 10 with moderation on Wednesday, Feb. 15.  The topic – human population over the past 11,700 years.

name: William Bremen
comment info:
1. There is a strong, positive correlation between friends made and increase in income, most likely because more high income people attend college than low income people. This graph's scale presents additional information not seen in the others; the top end of collegiate friend-makers are 2.4x the national average, significantly higher than the next highest proportion, low income people in the neighborhood. One interpretation of this data is that the highest earners in our society exclusively draw social connections from the elite institutions they attend. There may be some cause and effect relationship here, but that is definitely another question. The social effect of this phenomenon is most certainly noticeable in our society, where wealthy people stay insulated within themselves, and as the graph shows, rarely interact with those in their neighborhood.
2. I wonder if there is a cause and effect relationship between these studied variables. Are wealthy people more likely to have become wealthy if they made more friends in college?
3. It's interesting that high school is the most even time for friend development as there is generally limited variation across the income spectrum. It's apparently a great environment for interclass interaction and bonding. That's got to be good for our communities.
4. "Finding Our Friends: A Study of Income and Where We Build Friendships"

name: Mollie Lemasters
comment info: What I take from this graph is that the proportion of friends made from high school or work settings is approximately equal between lower and higher incomes. This makes sense because almost the entire population would be engaged in high school and work environments. However, when it comes to college, there is a strong correlation between higher income and friends made in college; this makes sense because generally, careers stemming from a college education have higher incomes, and therefore those with higher incomes would have likely gone to college, and consequently made more friends in college. When it comes to neighborhoods, there is a strong correlation between lower incomes and making friends. This also makes sense because those who have higher incomes are less likely to live in communal neighborhoods, and therefore are less likely to make friends within a neighborhood. This graph is, as a gestalt, commenting on the fact that everyone makes friends in their own group, more likely or unlikely based on the fact that lower incomes are correlated with neighborhood living, and higher incomes are correlated with college and higher education. I would name this graph “Everyone Has Friends Somewhere”

name: Cameron Woan
comment info:
1. It seems as though income disparity shines most brightly in places where not all tax brackets will be represented equally. Take the college graph, the clearest indicator of a correlation between wealth and the ability to make friends. First and foremost, lower-income families and children from those families don't have access to college, but that's relatively clear and obvious. What isn't so obvious is the fact that those few low-income children who do have the chance to go to college might a. have to work a job in order to pay their tuition or b. they're hyper-aware of the opportunity college presents and they want to make the best of it. 

2. What questions is this supposed to raise? We know there's a huge educational schism between the wealthy and the poor, so what can be done to not only bridge the gap educationally but also make the experiences of those low-income students more beneficial from a social standpoint.

3.  I'm fortunate enough to go to a really fantastic school with incredible people and teachers surrounding me every day, but I've never taken any time to consider the effects that come from a different socioeconomic class that the majority of students in the school come from might mean socially. I understand that the data references both high school and college, but I'm curious to see if there's a divide in that high school data between public and private high schools. 

4. A Friendly Investment: The Cost of Friendship

name: Carlos B.
comment info: It seems that these graphs are showing that in different areas the amount of income you bring in has different effect on the amount of friends you make. This relates to my community because in my high school we are all in the same income range and it seems that almost of us have a good friend group.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Carlos B. --

Take another look at the explanations on the y-axis (for example, 2.4x more likely than average) and the first sentence in the paragraph under the graphs.  Are these graphs showing number or proportions?  How does this change your noticings?  Also, meeting friends is in the past; the income is from recently.  How would this change your responses?
Now, notice and wonder.
